morePosts.title: Why Your Programming Skills will not gonna Obsolete as Fast as You ThinK!@@:)

metadata.content:
I encounter a few things about learning comp sci and programming languages.

As a part of my program, I have to learn several different programming languages like 
C, C++, PHP, Python, Java, etc. OR Databases such as Mysql. And Operating
system.
As I thought. I need to purchase new books to study to keep pace with my course.
But after carefully going through all topics. I noticed I don't need to buy any resources to study Whichever few subjects such as python. I have all materials.

Even though my books were published 20 years before. **My Java complete reference **published in 2003.

It is still relevant for my academic study. As it covers 90â„… of my need. As I am not going to in detail as I have more than 14 subjects in my curriculum. Java is one of my eg.

Here few points drawn as a conclusion.

Don't blindly run behind every programming language hot in the current market.

FOCUS ON FUNDAMENTALS

Most technologies evolve with time. It is not easy to replace with a new funky easy-
to-use or learn technology stack or programming languages time-tested stack.

For example, GO is a general-purpose language developed by google. But it can not suddenly, be replaced by C language overnight. It's a slow and tedious process. so go developers had to be patient as the market adopts it.

 After so many decades still, digital computers understand 0 & 1. Still, we can't use our natural language as a computer programming language.

There are so many things that are the same.
But It's nice to see what lies in the future.
# Some worthy classical mentions
- Modern operating systems by Andrew S. Tanenbaum
- Java: The Complete Reference by Herbert Schildt
- Head First C# by Andrew Stellman.
- Let Us C by Yashwant Kanetkar
- OBJECT ORIENTED Programming WITH C++ by E. Balagurusamy




Recently I read this amazing article which supports this argument.
https://www.toptal.com/c/after-all-these-years-the-world-is-still-powered-by-c-programming
